Aspiration of synovial fluid for culture and analysis is the best initial step in management. We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests a possible septic joint, and the best initial step in management would be joint aspiration for culture and analysis of the synovial fluid. CT scan is not necessary as there are no indications of fracture or other problems requiring imaging. Broad-spectrum antibiotics can be considered after joint aspiration if the culture is positive for an infection. Conservative therapy such as rest and analgesics can be used adjunctly with aspiration.

We refer to the UpToDate article on acute monoarthritis for help. The patient’s presentation suggests an acute inflammatory process in the joint. Aspirating the joint to detect possible infectious or crystal-induced arthritis is the best initial step in management. Broad-spectrum antibiotics may be indicated if the aspirate shows signs of infection. Conservative therapy, including rest, ice, and pain management, can be used in conjunction with aspiration. CT scan is not necessary for initial management.
